history.content:
I typically plan out what it is I want to do, then see if there are similar existing projects to give me a starting ground. Other things I’ll do will be to look for tutorials on how to set up a project in whatever framework, so I get an idea of how I build and test the code—doesn’t matter what you do if you can’t actually use it. 

For learning something like react, I find a few starter tutorials to give me a good grounding in the basics, and then learn things on the fly as I need to to figure out how to do something. There’s also plenty of advanced tutorials on the various languages/frameworks work that you can use to dive in, if you want a really deep understanding. Reading the APIs are always helpful too. 

You can also pseudocode out how each piece of functionality would work, design the algorithms, then research how you would implement it using the framework (or in the case of node, if there’s modules that will achieve what you want, i.e. yargs for command line argument parsing), and read the documentation.

As an aside, you should add electron to that list; it’s a great technology to pick up and it fits well with what you intend to learn. It has a low entry threshold, and plenty of advanced subjects to keep you busy.

Other things I’ll do will be to look for tutorials on how to set up a project in whatever framework, so I get an idea of how I build and test the code—doesn’t matter what you do if you can’t actually use it. 

For learning something like react, I find a few starter tutorials to give me a good grounding in the basics, and then learn things on the fly as I need to to figure out how to do something. There’s also plenty of advanced tutorials on the various languages/frameworks work that you can use to dive in, if you want a really deep understanding. Reading the APIs are always helpful too. 

You can also pseudocode out how each piece of funcationality would work, design the algorithms, then research how you would implement it using the framework (or in the case of node, if there’s modules that will achieve what you want, i.e. yargs for command line argument parsing), and read the documentation.

As an aside, you should add electron to that list; it’s a great technology to pick up and it fits well with what you intend to learn. It has a low entry threshold, and plenty of advanced subjects to keep you busy.

Over the summer I want to learn some relevant technologies such as React, Node, and other popular frameworks and libraries. I decided building a project that implements some of these would be a good way to build experience in these technologies. However, I am having trouble figuring out where to start in learning how to use these new technologies. I find it difficult to build something from scratch using something I have never seen before, and I was wondering how others approach self-studying this kind of stuff. Thanks!
history.subject: Advice for Learning New Technologies
